review.title: Probabilistic Acceptance
review.abstract: The idea of fully accepting statements when the evidence has rendered them probable enough faces a number of difficulties. We leave the interpretation of probability largely open, but attempt to suggest a contextual approach to full belief. We show that the difficulties of probabilistic acceptance are not as severe as they are sometimes painted, and that though there are oddities associated with probabilistic acceptance they are in some instances less awkward than the difficulties associated with other nonmonotonic formalisms. We show that the structure at which we arrive provides a natural home for statistical inference.

sections.text: We leave the interpretation of probability largely open, but try to propose a contextual concept based on complete faith. We show that the defamations of perception are not as difficult as they are sometimes presented, and that, although there are oddities that make them less cumbersome in some areas than the defamations associated with other non-monotonous formalisms, we show that the structure in which we arrive is a natural home for statistical inferences. You and I often jump to conclusions that are not severe enough to have evidence and background knowledge that we do not always act irrationally.
